benchmark_details.name: MCPTox
benchmark_details.overview: MCPTox is the first benchmark designed to systematically evaluate Tool Poisoning Attacks within the real-world Model Context Protocol ecosystem. It enables a standardized and realistic evaluation of agent robustness against Tool Poisoning attacks, featuring 1312 malicious test cases generated from 353 authentic tools across 45 live MCP servers.
benchmark_details.data_type: test cases with malicious instruction descriptions

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a comprehensive evaluation of LLM agents' vulnerabilities to Tool Poisoning attacks and to promote the development of safer AI agents.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Single-turn interaction; does not model long-term, conversational interactions.

data.source: Data consists of malicious test cases generated using state-of-the-art language models based on tool descriptions from real-world MCP servers.
data.annotation: Generated using semi-automated processes assisted by human verification.

methodology.calculation: Attack Success Rate is calculated as the number of successful attacks divided by the total number of valid outputs.
methodology.interpretation: An ASR approaching 100% indicates a high vulnerability to Tool Poisoning; lower values suggest better resilience.
methodology.baseline_results: Highest attack success rate observed was 72.8% for specific LLM models.
methodology.validation: Validated against real-world MCP servers ensuring realistic evaluation conditions.

targeted_risks.harm: Potential exfiltration of sensitive information and manipulation of legitimate tool actions.
